title: Brain Death Evaluation / Death by Neurologic Criteria
scope: ** Comprehensive evaluation and determination of brain death (death by neurologic criteria) in adults per AAN 2023 updated practice guideline. Covers prerequisites for testing, clinical examination (coma and brainstem reflex testing), apnea test protocol, ancillary testing indications and options, documentation requirements, family communication, legal/ethical considerations, organ procurement organization (OPO) notification, and donor management protocols. Excludes pediatric brain death determination (different age-specific criteria per AAP/CNS/SCCM guidelines), determination in neonates, and determination in patients on ECMO (requires institutional-specific protocols).

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: **PREREQUISITE**: Hypothermia must be excluded as confounder; core temp ≥36°C (96.8°F) required before examination
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Core temperature ≥36°C (96.8°F); if hypothermic, actively rewarm before proceeding

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: **PREREQUISITE**: Exclude severe metabolic derangement as confounder; electrolytes, glucose, renal and hepatic function
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: No severe metabolic derangement: sodium 115-160 mEq/L; glucose >54 mg/dL; no hepatic encephalopathy; no severe uremia

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: **PREREQUISITE**: Hypoglycemia can mimic brain death; must be excluded
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Glucose >54 mg/dL (>3 mmol/L); if low, correct and reassess

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: **PREREQUISITE**: Baseline before apnea test; assess acid-base status; ensure adequate pre-oxygenation; confirm PaCO2 baseline
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Pre-apnea test baseline: PaCO2 35-45 mmHg; pH 7.35-7.45; PaO2 >200 mmHg (after pre-oxygenation); post-apnea: PaCO2 ≥60 mmHg AND ≥20 mmHg above baseline

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Exclude hyperosmolar state as confounder; assess for severe dehydration
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: <320 mOsm/kg; severe hyperosmolality may confound examination

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: **PREREQUISITE**: Exclude CNS depressant drug intoxication as confounder; sedatives, narcotics, paralytics, barbiturates, alcohol
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Negative for CNS depressants; if positive, must wait for clearance (5 half-lives) or use ancillary testing

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: If any CNS depressant administered: measure specific drug levels; barbiturate, benzodiazepine, opioid, propofol levels
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Below therapeutic/active levels; barbiturates <10 mcg/mL; midazolam <50 ng/mL; propofol: discontinued ≥5 half-lives

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Baseline; infection assessment; evaluate for sepsis as potential confounder; organ donation workup
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Normal or interpretable in context; severe sepsis/septic shock may confound

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Baseline coagulation; organ donation workup; procedural planning
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: Normal or correctable; coagulopathy does not preclude brain death testing

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Assess tissue perfusion; hemodynamic adequacy for valid examination
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: <4 mmol/L preferred; severe shock must be treated before valid examination

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Organ donation preparedness; potential surgical procedures
Exclude severe hypothyroidism (myxedema coma) as confounder; donor management (hormone replacement therapy protocol)
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: TSH and free T4 within range that excludes myxedema; if severely abnormal, correct or use ancillary testing

Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.rationale: Donor management protocol (assess adrenal function); severe adrenal insufficiency as confounder (rare)
Essential/Core Labs (Prerequisites — Mus.target: >10 mcg/dL (random); if low, initiate stress-dose steroids for donor management

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: **CRITICAL for apnea test**: Pre-test baseline PaCO2 → post-test PaCO2 must rise ≥60 mmHg AND ≥20 mmHg above baseline
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: Pre-test: PaCO2 35-45 mmHg; PaO2 >200 after pre-oxygenation; Post-test: PaCO2 ≥60 AND ≥20 above baseline = positive (absent respiratory drive)

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Diabetes insipidus is common in brain death (posterior pituitary failure); rapidly rising sodium indicates DI
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: Watch for rapid sodium rise >145 mEq/L; rising >2-3 mEq/L/hr suggests diabetes insipidus; initiate desmopressin

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Diabetes insipidus detection; polyuria >250-300 mL/hr or >3 mL/kg/hr with dilute urine indicates DI
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: <200 mL/hr; if >300 mL/hr with serum Na rising and urine specific gravity <1.005 → DI; treat with desmopressin

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Confirm diabetes insipidus if polyuria present; dilute urine with rising serum sodium
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: Urine specific gravity >1.005; if <1.005 with polyuria and hypernatremia → DI confirmed

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Neurogenic cardiac injury assessment; organ donation cardiac evaluation
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: Normal or mildly elevated acceptable; severely elevated → echocardiography for donation evaluation
Normal or mildly elevated; guides cardiac donation suitability

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Infection evaluation; organ donation infectious disease screening
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: <0.5 ng/mL preferred; elevated → evaluate for infection source; does not preclude donation

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Organ donation infectious disease screening; evaluate for sepsis
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: No growth; if positive → treat and evaluate donation eligibility per OPO protocols
Negative; if UTI → treat; does not preclude donation

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.item: HIV, Hepatitis B surface Ag, Hepatitis B core Ab, Hepatitis C Ab (CPT 86689, 87340, 86704, 86803)
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: **Required for organ donation**: Infectious disease screening per UNOS requirements
Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: Negative preferred; positive results do not absolutely preclude donation (NAT testing; risk-assessed donors)

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.rationale: Organ donation viral serology; recipient matching

Extended Workup (Serial / Monitoring / O.target: <6.5% preferred for pancreas donation; elevated → may preclude pancreas but not other organs
Normal; elevated → evaluate pancreas suitability for donation

Rare/Specialized.item: Quantitative drug levels (barbiturate, benzodiazepine, propofol metabolite)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: When specific CNS depressant clearance must be confirmed; if standard toxicology screen insufficient
Rare/Specialized.target: Below threshold that could confound examination: pentobarbital <10 mcg/mL; phenobarbital <10 mcg/mL; midazolam <50 ng/mL

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If Guillain-Barre (Miller Fisher variant) suspected as mimic; areflexia with ophthalmoplegia
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; if positive → GBS mimic, NOT brain death; requires alternative evaluation

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Exclude severe hepatic encephalopathy as confounder
Rare/Specialized.target: <200 μmol/L; severely elevated ammonia (>200) may confound clinical exam; treat hepatic failure first

Rare/Specialized.rationale: **PREREQUISITE if neuromuscular blocking agents administered**: Must confirm 4/4 twitches (complete recovery from paralysis) before clinical examination
Rare/Specialized.target: 4 of 4 twitches present (full neuromuscular recovery); if <4/4, examination is invalid — wait for clearance or use ancillary test

Essential/First-line (Establish Etiology.timing: **PREREQUISITE** — Must establish known structural cause of brain death; imaging before examination
Essential/First-line (Establish Etiology.target: Identified catastrophic brain injury: massive stroke, hemorrhage, anoxic injury (diffuse edema, loss of gray-white differentiation), herniation, absence of intracranial blood flow (dense MCA sign); must establish irreversible cause

Essential/First-line (Establish Etiology.timing: If etiology unclear; may serve as ancillary test for cerebral circulatory arrest if performed per protocol
Essential/First-line (Establish Etiology.target: Absence of intracranial arterial opacification (if used as ancillary test); identifies vascular cause (massive stroke, SAH)
Essential/First-line (Establish Etiology.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); renal impairment (acceptable if donation anticipated)

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Gold standard ancillary test; when clinical testing cannot be completed
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: **Absence of intracerebral filling** at the level of the carotid bifurcation or circle of Willis; external carotid filling may be present; delayed filling up to the proximal segments does NOT exclude brain death if no intracerebral filling
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: Contrast allergy; hemodynamic instability (relative — may require vasopressor support during procedure); renal impairment (acceptable if donation anticipated)

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.item: Technetium-99m HMPAO SPECT brain perfusion scan (CPT 78607)
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Radionuclide cerebral perfusion study; widely available; high sensitivity and specificity
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: **"Hollow skull" phenomenon**: Complete absence of intracranial tracer uptake; no perfusion to cerebral hemispheres or brainstem; scalp and facial blood flow present (external carotid territory)
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: None absolute; limited availability of isotope in some centers; patient must be transported to nuclear medicine (logistically challenging for unstable patients)

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.item: Technetium-99m pertechnetate cerebral blood flow study (CPT 78610)
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Alternative radionuclide study; more widely available than HMPAO
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: Absence of intracranial blood flow on anterior and lateral views; "empty light bulb" sign; less sensitive for posterior fossa/brainstem than HMPAO-SPECT
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: Same as above; pertechnetate less specific than HMPAO for posterior fossa

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Demonstrates electrocerebral inactivity (ECI); 16+ channel recording per ACNS guidelines
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: **Electrocerebral inactivity (ECI):** No electrical activity >2 μV over 30 minutes of recording; must use minimum 16 channels; interelectrode distances ≥10 cm; impedances 100-10,000 ohms; sensitivity 2 μV/mm; high-frequency filter ≤70 Hz; low-frequency filter ≤1 Hz
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: Does NOT assess brainstem function directly; can be confounded by sedatives, hypothermia, metabolic derangement; artifact from ICU environment; should NOT be sole ancillary test if brainstem assessment incomplete

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Non-invasive vascular study; increasingly used; AAN 2023 acknowledges but notes variable sensitivity
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: Absence of opacification of cortical segments of MCA, cortical segments of ACA, and internal cerebral veins (7-point CTA scoring system); some protocols assess 4-point or 10-point systems
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment; false negatives possible (sensitivity 85-95% depending on protocol and timing of image acquisition)

Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.timing: Non-invasive bedside study; can be repeated; useful for trending toward brain death
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.target: **Cerebral circulatory arrest pattern:** Reverberating (oscillating) flow pattern; small systolic spikes (<50 cm/s duration <200 ms); absent diastolic flow → absent flow in all assessed vessels; must assess bilateral MCA AND basilar artery
Ancillary Tests (When Clinical Examinati.contraindications: Operator-dependent; 10-15% of patients have inadequate temporal windows; not universally accepted as sole ancillary test; AAN 2023: acceptable if institutional protocol supports; cannot assess in presence of craniectomy defects

Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.timing: Rarely used for brain death determination; may demonstrate diffuse injury; MRA may show absent flow
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.target: Diffuse cortical and brainstem injury; absent intracranial arterial flow on MRA; tonsillar herniation; diffuse restricted diffusion on DWI
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.contraindications: MRI-incompatible devices; hemodynamic instability; transport risk; prolonged study time in unstable patient

Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.timing: Assesses brainstem and cortical conduction; bilateral median nerve stimulation
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.target: Bilateral absence of N20 cortical response with preserved Erb point potential (peripheral nerve intact, cortex non-functional); does NOT assess brainstem directly
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.contraindications: Peripheral neuropathy may confound; requires intact peripheral nerve; not widely available for acute bedside use

Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.timing: Assesses auditory brainstem pathway; complements EEG (which only assesses cortex)
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.target: Absence of all waveforms beyond wave I (wave I may be present — cochlear origin; absence of waves III and V = brainstem non-function)
Rare/Advanced Ancillary Tests.contraindications: Middle ear pathology; peripheral hearing loss; limited availability

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Hypothermia correction; core temperature must be ≥36°C before examination

dosing.instructions: Warm IV fluids 40-42°C; forced air warming blankets; warmed humidified ventilator gases; if severe hypothermia: peritoneal lavage, bladder irrigation, or extracorporeal rewarming; must achieve target before proceeding

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.contraindications: None; must achieve target before proceeding
Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: Core temperature continuous monitoring (esophageal, rectal, or bladder probe); target ≥36°C

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Diabetes insipidus treatment (common in brain death due to pituitary failure); maintain hemodynamic stability for valid examination

dosing.instructions: 1-4 mcg IV q6-12h; titrate to urine output <200-300 mL/hr; may also give 10-20 mcg intranasally; onset IV: 15-30 min; adjust based on urine output and sodium

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: Urine output hourly; serum sodium q2-4h; urine specific gravity; serum osmolality; goal UOP 0.5-3 mL/kg/hr

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Volume resuscitation for hemodynamic stability; replace massive urine losses from DI; maintain adequate perfusion for valid examination

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Isotonic crystalloid (0.9% NaCl or LR)** 0.9% NaCl IV

dosing.instructions: Bolus 500-1000 mL for hypotension; maintenance 100-250 mL/hr; replace urine output mL-for-mL if DI present; avoid hypotonic fluids
dosing.orderSentence: **Isotonic crystalloid (0.9% NaCl or LR)** 0.9% NaCl IV

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.contraindications: Fluid overload; pulmonary edema (balance with organ preservation goals)
Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: CVP if available; urine output; serum sodium; blood pressure; lung auscultation

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Vasopressor for hemodynamic support; neurogenic shock (loss of sympathetic tone) common in brain death; maintain MAP ≥60 mmHg for valid examination

dosing.instructions: Start 0.05-0.1 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP ≥60 mmHg (or ≥70 for donor management); max 0.5 mcg/kg/min; consider adding vasopressin if escalating

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: Continuous arterial BP monitoring; MAP target ≥60; assess for adequate organ perfusion; limit escalation if possible for donor management

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Adjunct vasopressor; particularly useful in brain death (endogenous vasopressin deficiency from pituitary failure); hemodynamic support + DI treatment

dosing.instructions: Start 0.01 units/min; titrate to MAP ≥60 mmHg; max 0.04 units/min for vasopressor effect; also treats DI at higher doses; AAN/HRSA donor management: 1 unit IV bolus then 0.5-2.4 units/hr

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.contraindications: High-dose may cause mesenteric ischemia; coronary vasoconstriction
Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: MAP continuous; urine output hourly; lactate; assess perfusion; cardiac telemetry

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.indication: Exclude metabolic confounders; sodium, glucose, pH, calcium must be within acceptable ranges

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Correction of metabolic derangements** Per derangement IV

dosing.instructions: Correct sodium to 115-160 mEq/L range; glucose >54 mg/dL (D50 50 mL if needed); correct severe acidosis (NaHCO3 if pH <7.2); correct severe hypocalcemia (calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV); correct hypothyroidism
dosing.orderSentence: **Correction of metabolic derangements** Per derangement IV

Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.contraindications: Overly rapid sodium correction (risk of osmotic demyelination — less relevant in brain death but important for organ preservation)
Confounder Management (Prerequisites Bef.monitoring: Serial electrolytes q2-4h; glucose q1-2h; ABG q4h; target physiologic ranges

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Prevent hypoxia during apnea test; build oxygen reservoir

dosing.instructions: Pre-oxygenate with FiO2 1.0 (100% O2) for ≥10 minutes before disconnection; confirm PaO2 >200 mmHg on pre-apnea ABG

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: ABG after 10 min pre-oxygenation; SpO2 continuous; confirm PaO2 >200 mmHg

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Establish PaCO2 baseline; must be 35-45 mmHg before starting apnea test

dosing.instructions: Draw ABG after pre-oxygenation; adjust ventilator to normalize PaCO2 if needed; if baseline PaCO2 chronically elevated (e.g., COPD), target must be ≥20 mmHg above chronic baseline AND ≥60 mmHg

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).contraindications: If PaCO2 cannot be normalized to 35-45 (chronic hypercarbia), document chronic baseline and adjust targets accordingly
Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: PaCO2 35-45 mmHg; pH 7.35-7.45; if chronically elevated CO2, document baseline

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Apnea test initiation; remove external respiratory drive; observe for spontaneous respiratory effort

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Step 3: Disconnect ventilator and apply O2** 6-10 L/min O2 Intratracheal

dosing.instructions: Disconnect from ventilator; immediately place O2 cannula into trachea (or T-piece with CPAP at 5-10 cmH2O) delivering 6-10 L/min O2 at carina level; ensures oxygenation without ventilation
dosing.orderSentence: **Step 3: Disconnect ventilator and apply O2** 6-10 L/min O2 Intratracheal

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).contraindications: Severe ARDS with FiO2 >0.7 and PEEP >10 (may desaturate rapidly — consider ancillary test instead); hemodynamic instability (relative)
Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: SpO2 continuous; arterial line continuous; direct observation for ANY respiratory movement (chest, abdomen)

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Detect any spontaneous breathing; absence confirms apnea

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Step 4: Observe for respiratory effort** 8-10 min Visual

dosing.instructions: Observe 8-10 minutes (AAN 2023); watch for ANY chest or abdominal respiratory movements; look at proximal ETT for condensation/gas movement; if ANY respiratory effort observed → ABORT: patient is NOT brain dead
dosing.orderSentence: **Step 4: Observe for respiratory effort** 8-10 min Visual

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).contraindications: SpO2 <85% despite O2 supplementation; severe hemodynamic instability (MAP <60 despite vasopressors); dangerous cardiac arrhythmia
Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: Visual observation: chest wall, abdomen; SpO2; BP continuous; cardiac telemetry; 8-10 min observation minimum

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Confirm PaCO2 rise meets threshold for valid test

dosing.instructions: Draw ABG at 8-10 minutes of apnea (or sooner if SpO2 <85%); POSITIVE (absent respiratory drive): PaCO2 ≥60 mmHg AND rise ≥20 mmHg above baseline

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).contraindications: If PaCO2 target not reached and test aborted for desaturation, test is INCONCLUSIVE — need ancillary test
Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: PaCO2 ≥60 mmHg AND ≥20 above baseline = POSITIVE (brain death); if target not met → repeat or ancillary test

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).indication: Resume mechanical ventilation after ABG drawn; restore hemodynamic stability

dosing.instructions: Reconnect to pre-test ventilator settings immediately after post-apnea ABG drawn; restore FiO2 1.0 temporarily; resume standard settings once stable

Apnea Test Protocol (Step-by-Step).monitoring: SpO2; BP; cardiac rhythm; ensure hemodynamic stability; resume standard ventilator settings

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Hemodynamic support and DI treatment; first-line vasopressor for brain-dead donors per UNOS/HRSA protocol

dosing.instructions: HRSA protocol: 1 unit IV bolus then 0.5-2.4 units/hr; titrate to MAP ≥60 mmHg; also treats DI; preferred over catecholamines (less myocardial oxygen demand)

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.contraindications: Mesenteric ischemia at high doses; coronary vasoconstriction
Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: MAP continuous; urine output hourly; serum sodium q2-4h; lactate q6h; target MAP 60-100 mmHg; CVP 4-12 mmHg

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for brain-dead donors; pituitary failure causes hypothyroidism; improves hemodynamic stability and organ function

dosing.instructions: HRSA protocol: 20 mcg IV bolus then 10 mcg/hr continuous infusion; alternative: T3 (liothyronine) 4 mcg IV bolus then 3 mcg/hr; improves cardiac output and donor hemodynamics

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: TSH, free T4 q6-12h; hemodynamic response; cardiac function

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Hormone replacement therapy component; reduces inflammation; supports hemodynamic stability; decreases vasopressor requirement; improves oxygenation

dosing.instructions: HRSA protocol: 15 mg/kg IV bolus (max 1 g); single dose; alternative: hydrocortisone 100 mg IV q8h or stress dose 50 mg q6h; reduces inflammatory cytokines; improves lung and cardiac donation outcomes

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: Blood glucose (hyperglycemia common); hemodynamic response; WBC (may be falsely elevated)

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Glycemic control during donor management; methylprednisolone and stress response cause hyperglycemia; tight glucose control improves organ preservation

dosing.instructions: Regular insulin infusion; target blood glucose 120-180 mg/dL; start if BG >150 mg/dL; titrate per institutional insulin drip protocol; avoid hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL)

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: Blood glucose q1-2h; potassium q4h; avoid hypoglycemia

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Diabetes insipidus treatment; maintain euvolemia and sodium homeostasis for organ preservation; most brain-dead patients develop DI

dosing.instructions: 1-4 mcg IV q6-12h PRN; titrate to urine output 0.5-3 mL/kg/hr; target sodium 135-155 mEq/L; may also give 10-20 mcg intranasally

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: Urine output hourly; serum sodium q2-4h; urine specific gravity; goal UOP 0.5-3 mL/kg/hr; serum osmolality

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Second-line vasopressor if vasopressin insufficient; maintain MAP ≥60 mmHg; minimize dose to reduce end-organ catecholamine toxicity

dosing.instructions: Start 0.05 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP ≥60; goal: minimize catecholamine use (excess catecholamines damage transplantable organs, especially heart); transition to vasopressin-dominant regimen

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.contraindications: Peripheral administration (central line required); excessive doses damage cardiac allografts
Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: MAP; cardiac function; troponin trends; try to wean as vasopressin and HRT take effect

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Maintain oxygenation; lung-protective ventilation preserves lungs for transplant

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Mechanical ventilation (lung-protective for donation)** TV 6-8 mL/kg IBW Ventilator

dosing.instructions: Tidal volume 6-8 mL/kg IBW; PEEP 5-10 cmH2O; FiO2 titrate to SpO2 >95%; target PaO2 >100 mmHg; recruitment maneuvers PRN; suction PRN; avoid excessive tidal volumes
dosing.orderSentence: **Mechanical ventilation (lung-protective for donation)** TV 6-8 mL/kg IBW Ventilator

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: ABG q4-6h; SpO2 continuous; CXR daily; peak and plateau pressures; compliance trending

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.indication: Euvolemia maintenance; organ perfusion; replace insensible and DI losses without fluid overload (damages lungs)

dosing.instructions: 0.9% NaCl or LR; titrate to CVP 4-12 mmHg (or PCWP 8-12 mmHg if PA catheter); avoid hypovolemia (organ ischemia) and hypervolemia (pulmonary edema); use balanced crystalloid; transfuse PRN (Hgb >7 g/dL)

Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.contraindications: Pulmonary edema (restrict fluids, add diuretics if lung preservation critical)
Donor Management Protocol (After Brain D.monitoring: CVP; urine output; lactate; hemodynamics; daily CXR; ECHO if available

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.indication: Must be discontinued ≥5 half-lives before clinical examination; active sedation invalidates brain death determination

dosing.orderSentence: All sedatives (propofol, midazolam, dexmedetomidine) - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.contraindications: Active sedation invalidates brain death examination
Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.monitoring: Drug levels if uncertain clearance; clinical assessment; ancillary testing if clearance uncertain

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.indication: Must be discontinued ≥5 half-lives before clinical examination; opioids suppress respiratory drive (invalidate apnea test)

dosing.orderSentence: All opioids (fentanyl, morphine, hydromorphone) - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.monitoring: Drug levels if uncertain clearance; naloxone reversal NOT sufficient (reversal may be incomplete; must confirm clearance)

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.indication: Must be fully reversed before clinical examination; paralysis prevents assessment of motor and respiratory function

dosing.orderSentence: Neuromuscular blocking agents (rocuronium, cisatracurium, vecuronium) - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.contraindications: Active paralysis completely invalidates all clinical brain death testing
Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.monitoring: Train-of-four monitoring: must show 4/4 twitches before examination; sugammadex reversal for rocuronium/vecuronium if needed; wait for spontaneous clearance of cisatracurium

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.item: Atropine (diagnostic test — should NOT be administered as treatment)
Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.indication: Atropine is used as a diagnostic test during brain death examination (IV bolus → no heart rate increase confirms vagal nucleus non-function); NOT a treatment

dosing.orderSentence: Atropine (diagnostic test — should NOT be administered as treatment) - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.contraindications: Not used therapeutically in this context; used diagnostically: 1 mg IV → if NO heart rate increase >3% → confirms brainstem non-function
Medications to AVOID During Brain Death.monitoring: Document pre- and post-atropine heart rate; absence of response supports brain death

Referrals & Consults.item: Notify attending physician and neurology/neurocritical care for brain death evaluation when clinical suspicion arises
Verify institutional brain death policy and state law requirements before proceeding
Contact Organ Procurement Organization (OPO) — REQUIRED by federal law when brain death is imminent or declared
Establish time of death as time of completion of brain death determination (final examination or ancillary test)
Ensure at least one independent qualified examiner for brain death determination
Document all prerequisites, clinical findings, and apnea test results on institutional brain death determination form

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Family meeting to explain prognosis, brain death concept, and planned evaluation process BEFORE beginning testing
Provide family with explanation that brain death IS legal death in all 50 US states (with NJ religious exemption)
Social work and chaplain/spiritual care consultation for family support
Palliative care consultation for family support and goals-of-care discussion if determination is delayed or contested
Communicate with OPO regarding family approach timing and strategy
Provide family time with patient after brain death declaration and before organ recovery, if applicable

Legal, Ethical & Documentation.item: Complete institutional brain death determination checklist documenting all prerequisites and examination findings
Issue death certificate with time of death as moment of brain death declaration, NOT time of ventilator removal
Address religious/conscientious objections per state law (New Jersey Declaration of Death Act)
Ethics consultation if brain death determination is contested, delayed, or involves complex circumstances

differential.features: History of exposure; core temperature <32°C; can cause fixed dilated pupils, absent reflexes, flat EEG; FULLY REVERSIBLE; "no one is dead until warm and dead"
differential.tests: Core temperature measurement; actively rewarm to ≥36°C before brain death examination; all clinical findings may normalize with rewarming

differential.features: History of overdose or recent sedative administration; barbiturates, benzodiazepines, opioids, propofol, alcohol; can mimic all brain death findings including flat EEG
differential.tests: Comprehensive toxicology screen; specific drug levels; wait ≥5 half-lives for clearance; if cannot wait, use ancillary testing (cerebral blood flow study NOT affected by drugs)

differential.features: Hepatic encephalopathy (ammonia >200); severe hyponatremia or hypernatremia; diabetic coma; severe uremia; hyperosmolar state
differential.tests: CMP; ammonia; osmolality; ABG; correct derangement and reassess; if uncorrectable, ancillary testing

differential.features: Basilar artery occlusion/pontine stroke; patient is CONSCIOUS but appears unresponsive; preserved vertical eye movements and blinking; normal EEG
differential.tests: Ask patient to "look up" and "blink"; EEG shows normal alpha rhythm; MRI brainstem shows pontine lesion; brain death exam: pupils reactive, corneal reflex may be present

differential.features: Ascending paralysis; areflexia; may have facial diplegia and ophthalmoplegia; cranial nerve involvement can mimic brainstem areflexia
differential.tests: CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein, normal cells); NCS/EMG: demyelinating pattern; anti-GQ1b antibodies; EEG shows normal cerebral activity; cerebral blood flow is NORMAL

differential.features: Complete cord transection above C3 → apnea, quadriplegia, areflexia below lesion; BUT brainstem reflexes PRESERVED (pupillary, corneal, oculovestibular)
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine; brainstem reflexes intact on examination; EEG shows cerebral activity; cerebral blood flow normal

differential.features: Generalized weakness including cranial nerve and respiratory muscles; may appear unresponsive with absent reflexes; pupil reactivity usually preserved
differential.tests: Edrophonium/ice pack test; NCS with repetitive stimulation: decremental response; acetylcholine receptor antibodies; EEG: normal cerebral activity

differential.features: Intrathecal baclofen overdose can cause deep coma, areflexia, absent respiratory drive; REVERSIBLE
differential.tests: History of intrathecal baclofen pump; check pump function; CSF baclofen level; supportive care until clearance; EEG may show slowing but NOT electrocerebral inactivity; cerebral blood flow normal

differential.features: Acute cerebellar hemorrhage compressing brainstem; may present with absent brainstem reflexes; potentially surgically treatable
differential.tests: CT head: posterior fossa hemorrhage; neurosurgical evaluation for emergent decompression BEFORE declaring brain death; surgical evacuation may be life-saving

differential.features: Profound hypothermia, coma, hypoventilation, bradycardia; very slow reflexes may appear absent
differential.tests: TSH markedly elevated; free T4 very low; treat with IV levothyroxine and hydrocortisone; reassess after thyroid hormone replacement

differential.features: Eyes open, sleep-wake cycles, no awareness; brainstem function INTACT
differential.tests: NOT brain death — brainstem reflexes present; breathing spontaneously

differential.features: Inconsistent but reproducible evidence of awareness; follows commands intermittently
differential.tests: NOT brain death — evidence of consciousness

differential.features: Congenital absence of cerebral hemispheres; brainstem present and functioning
differential.tests: NOT brain death — brainstem functions intact; different legal/ethical considerations

monitoring.action: If <36°C: active rewarming; do NOT proceed with examination; if >38°C: cooling measures
Hypotension: IV fluids → vasopressin → norepinephrine; escalate per donor protocol
Arrhythmia: correct electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca); standard ACLS if needed; atropine test: no HR response expected in brain death
<85% during apnea test → ABORT test and reconnect ventilator; troubleshoot; consider ancillary testing
DI (>300 mL/hr, dilute urine, rising Na): desmopressin 1-4 mcg IV; replace volume; monitor sodium q2h
Rising Na + polyuria → DI → desmopressin + volume replacement; falling Na → adjust desmopressin
Acidosis: sodium bicarbonate if pH <7.2; ventilator adjustments; apnea test ABGs are critical for determination

monitoring.frequency: q1-2h during insulin drip; q4h otherwise
monitoring.action: <70: D50 bolus; >180: start/increase insulin infusion; steroid-induced hyperglycemia common

monitoring.item: Serial neurologic checks (GCS, pupils, brainstem reflexes)
monitoring.action: Any improvement → brain death cannot be diagnosed; reassess; look for confounders
Low: volume resuscitation; high: restrict fluids (protect lungs); diuretics if pulmonary edema
Rising troponin: echocardiography; may affect cardiac donation suitability; neurogenic cardiac injury common

disposition.criteria: All patients undergoing brain death evaluation require ICU-level care; mechanical ventilation; continuous hemodynamic monitoring; arterial line; vasopressor support; hourly neuro checks; controlled environment for apnea testing

After brain death declaration with organ donation consent: continue ICU-level care for donor management (hemodynamic optimization, hormone replacement, organ preservation); OPO manages care; OR scheduling for organ recovery

After brain death declaration WITHOUT organ donation: family notification → reasonable time for family to visit → ventilator discontinuation; patient is legally dead — ventilator removal is NOT "withdrawal of care"

After ventilator removal (non-donor) or after organ recovery (donor): standard post-mortem care; death certificate completed with time of brain death determination; autopsy per institutional/legal requirements

If confounders cannot be excluded (e.g., recent sedative administration): continue ICU care; repeat evaluation after drug clearance (≥5 half-lives); consider ancillary testing if clearance uncertain or delayed
If family contests: ethics consultation; social work; chaplain; legal counsel; reasonable accommodation; NJ religious exemption if applicable; continue ICU care during resolution
If institution lacks resources for ancillary testing: arrange transfer to facility with nuclear medicine, angiography, or neurophysiology capabilities; OPO may facilitate transfer
